# What Is a 'Transmission Line' (TL)?

A transmission line (TL) consists of two or more conductors separated from one another by a dielectric, like air, gaz or an insulating material such as polythene, teflon.

It can transmit electric energy, signals, data, and information from one point to another.

Cable television, broadband internet, antenna and transmitter/receiver.

Power lines, rural telephone lines, and telegraph lines.

Microwave and mm-wave applications: circuits, antennas, and components like circulators, filters, directional couplers, and power dividers.

# Transmission Line Definitions

Uniform TL - conductors and dielectrics maintain the same cross-sectional geometry along the TL

Transmission line mode - a distinct pattern of E and H fields induced on a TL.

Longitudinal components - the field components in the direction of wave propagation Transverse components - the field components perpendicular to the direction of propagation

# Electromagnetic Fields In The Transmission Line

# Problem:

A transmission line of length $l$ connects a load to a sinusoidal voltage source with frequency $f$. Assuming the velocity of wave propagation on the line is $c$, which of the following situations is reasonable to ignore the presence of the transmission line in the solution of the circuit:

(a) $l=20\ cm$, $f=20\ kHz$, (b) $l=50\ km$, $f=60\ Hz$, (c) $l=20\ cm$, $f=600\ MHz$, (d) $l=1\ mm$, $f=100\ GHz$

# Solution:

A transmission line is negligible when $l/\lambda \leq 0.01$

(a) $\frac{l}{\lambda}=\frac{lf}{c}=\frac{(20\times10^{-2}m)\times(20\times10^{3}Hz)}{3\times10^{8}m/s}=1.33\times10^{-5}$ negligible

(b) $\frac{l}{\lambda}=\frac{lf}{c}=\frac{(50\times10^{3}m)\times(60Hz)}{3\times10^{8}m/s}=0.01$ borderline

(c) $\frac{l}{\lambda}=\frac{lf}{c}=\frac{(20\times10^{-2}m)\times(600\times10^{6}Hz)}{3\times10^{8}m/s}=0.4$ nonnegligible

(d) $\frac{l}{\lambda}=\frac{lf}{c}=\frac{(1\times10^{-3}m)\times(100\times10^{9}Hz)}{3\times10^{8}m/s}=0.33$ nonnegligible

# Transmission Line Model (Lumped-Element)

An equivalent circuit of a TL can be developed by considering two-wire li The equivalent circuit i.e., transmission line model represents the TL as a cascade of identical cells of infinitesimal length $\Delta z$. The cell represents a piece of line of infinitesimal length $\Delta z$. It can be nodeled as a lumped-element circuit.

$R'$: The combined resistance of both conductors per unit length, in $\Omega$/m,

$L'$: The combined inductance of both conductors per unit length, in H/m,

$G'$: The conductance of the insulation medium between the two conductors per unit length, in S/m, and

$C'$: The capacitance of the two conductors per unit length, in F/m.

![](images/76fdbec72d6e341dc98713bd1dfa73c597ae4ba9a8006f1c8989d0e3e7cd92cb_44.jpg){width=44%} (c) Each section is represented by an equivalent circuit

# TL Model: Lumped Element Model (Cont.)

The wires are of uniform size, the RESISTANCE of the conducting material of which the wires are made can be assumed to be uniformly distributed along their lengths.

The magnetic field links the wires and hence an INDUCTANCE is said to be present. This is distributed uniformly along the length of the line. Since this inductance impedes current flow, it is effectively in series with the uniformly distributed resistance.

The fact that the input and output currents are different suggests the possibility of an ADMITTANCE between the wires. This shunt admittance consists of a conductance and a capacitance in parallel.

The presence of CAPACITANCE is because the line consists of two conductors separated by an air dielectric.

Because the dielectric is not perfect, a conduction current will flow between the wires. A conductance between the cables can represent this leakage path.

LEAKAGE CURRENT flows between the two wires due to the dielectric, even air, is not a perfect insulator, a small current known as. In effect, the insulator acts as a resistor, permitting current to pass between the two wires.

# TL Model: Lumped Element Model (Cont.)

This property is called CONDUCTANCE and is the opposite of resistance. Conductance in transmission lines is expressed as the reciprocal of resistance.

LUMPED constants are theoretical properties (inductance, resistance, capacitance, conductance) of a transmission line that are lumped into a single element.

# TL Model: Lumped Element Model (Cont.)

Transmission-line parameters $R'$, $L'$, $G'$, and $C'$ for three types of lines.

| Parameter | Coaxial | Two-Wire | Parallel-Plate | Unit |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| $R'$ | $\frac{R_{\rm S}}{2\pi}\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}\right)$ | $\frac{2R_{\rm S}}{\pi d}$ | $\frac{2R_{\rm S}}{w}$ | $$\Omega$/m$ |
| $L'$ | $\frac{\mu}{2\pi}\ln(b/a)$ | $\frac{\mu}{\pi}\ln\left[\left(D/d\right)+\sqrt{(D/d)^2-1}\right]$ | $\frac{\mu h}{w}$ | $H/m$ |
| $G'$ | $\frac{2\pi\sigma}{\ln(b/a)}$ | $\overline{\frac{\pi\sigma}{\ln\left[(D/d) + \sqrt{(D/d)^2-1}\right]}$ | $\frac{\sigma w}{h}$ | $S/m$ |
| $C'$ | $\frac{2\pi\varepsilon}{\ln(b/a)}$ | $\overline{\frac{\pi\varepsilon}{\ln\left[(D/d) + \sqrt{(D/d)^2-1}\right]}$ | $\varepsilon w$ | $F/m$ |
| $Notes: $\mu$, $\varepsilon$, and $\sigma$ pertain to the insulating material between the conductors. $R_{\rm s}=\sqrt{\pi f\mu_{\rm c}/\sigma_{\rm c}}$. $\mu_{\rm c}$ and $\sigma_{\rm c}$ pertain to the conductors. If $(D/d)^2\gg 1$, then $\ln\left[(D/d)+\sqrt{(D/d)^2-1}\right]\simeq\ln(2D/d)$.$ |

The pertinent constitutive parameters apply to all three lines and consist of two groups: (1) $\mu_{\mathrm{c}}$ and $\sigma_{\mathrm{c}}$ are the magnetic permeability and electrical conductivity of the conductors, and (2) $\varepsilon$, $\mu$, and $\sigma$ are the electrical permittivity, magnetic permeability, and electrical conductivity of the insulation material separating them.

# Telegrapher's equations

$$
\begin{array}{rl} & { - \frac { d \tilde { V } ( z ) } { d z } = ( R ^{\prime} + j \omega L ^{\prime} ) \, \tilde { I } ( z ) , } \\& { - \frac { d \tilde { I } ( z ) } { d z } = ( G ^{\prime} + j \omega C ^{\prime} ) \, \tilde { V } ( z ) . } \end{array}
$$

Frequency-domain (phasor) transmission line equations (coupled DE's)

ac signals: use phasors

$$
\begin{array}{r} { v ( z , t ) = \Re \mathrm { e } [ \widetilde V ( z ) \, e ^{j \omega t} ] , } \\{ i ( z , t ) = \Re \mathrm { e } [ \tilde { I } ( z ) \, e ^{j \omega t} ] , } \end{array}
$$

# Remember

Kirchhoff Voltage Law

$V_{in}^{-}V_{out} - V_{R'} - V_{L'} = 0$

Kirchhoff Current Law

$I_{in}^{-}I_{out} - I_{C'} - I_{G'} = 0$

# Note:

$V_{L}=\mathrm{\~L\~}\frac{di}{dt}$

$I_{C}=\mathrm{C}\frac{dv}{dt}$

# Derivation of Wave Equations

$$
\begin{array}{rl} & {  - \frac { d \widetilde V ( z ) } { d z } = ( R ^{\prime} + j \omega L ^{\prime} ) \, \widetilde I ( z ) , } \\& {  - \frac { d \widetilde I ( z ) } { d z } = ( G ^{\prime} + j \omega C ^{\prime} ) \, \widetilde V ( z ) . } \end{array}
$$

Combining the two equations leads to:

$$
\frac { d ^{2} \tilde { V } ( z ) } { d z ^{2} } - ( R ^{\prime} + j \omega L ^{\prime} ) ( G ^{\prime} + j \omega C ^{\prime} ) \, \tilde { V } ( z ) = 0 ,
$$

$$
\frac { d ^{2} \widetilde V ( z ) } { d z ^{2} } - \gamma ^{2} \, \widetilde V ( z ) = 0 ,
$$

Second-order differential equation

$$
\gamma = \sqrt { ( R ^{\prime} + j \omega L ^{\prime} ) ( G ^{\prime} + j \omega C ^{\prime} ) } .
$$

![](images/3ba8336e3450e480d5b4e4ae37bacd3a81793d48e43618e4882836fda179425a_46.jpg){width=46%}

$$
\begin{array}{rl} & { \alpha = \Re ( \gamma ) } \\& { = \Re \left( \sqrt { ( R ^{\prime} + j \omega L ^{\prime} ) ( G ^{\prime} + j \omega C ^{\prime} ) } \right) ~ ~ ~ ( \mathrm { N p / m } ) , } \end{array}
$$

$$
\begin{array}{rl} & { \beta = \Im m ( \gamma ) } \\& { = \Im m \left( \sqrt { ( R ^{\prime} + j \omega L ^{\prime} ) ( G ^{\prime} + j \omega C ^{\prime} ) } \right) ~ ~ ~ \mathrm { ( r a d / m ) . } } \end{array}
$$

$$

# Special Case #2 Distortionless TL

The velocity of propagation on the typical non-ideal TL is a function of frequency so that signals are distorted as different components of the signal arrive at the load at different times. This effect is called dispersion

A dispersive medium is characterized by a phase velocity which is a function of frequency.

There is a special case of lossy line with the linear phase constant that produces a distortionless line.

ATL can be made distortionless by designing the line such that the per-unit-length parameters satisfy

$$
{ \frac { R } { L } } = { \frac { G } { C } }  \mathrm { ( d i s t o r t i o n l e s s ~ l i n e ) }
$$

<br><span class='markdown-page-line'>---------------------------------------------<span id='page25' class='markdown-page-text'>[ 第25页 ]</span>---------------------------------------------</span><br><br>

Inserting the per-unit-length parameter relationship into the general equation for the propagation constant on a lossy line gives

$$
\begin{aligned} \gamma & = \sqrt { ( R + j \omega L ) ( G + j \omega C ) } \\& = \sqrt { R \left( 1 + j \omega \frac { L } { R } \right) G \left( 1 + j \omega \frac { C } { G } \right) } \\& = \sqrt { R G \left( 1 + j \omega \frac { L } { R } \right) ^{2} } \\& = \sqrt { R G \left( 1 + j \omega \frac { L } { R } \right) } = \alpha + j \beta \\\alpha & = \sqrt { R G } &  \beta = \omega \sqrt { R G } \frac { L } { R } = \omega \sqrt { \frac { G } { R } L } = \omega \sqrt { \frac { C } { L } } L = \omega \sqrt { L C } \end{aligned}
$$

# Notes

Although the shape of the signal is not distorted, the signal will suffer attenuation as the wave propagates along the line since the distortionless line is a lossy TL.

The attenuation constant for a distortionless TL is independent of frequency.

In the previous derivation, we have assumed that the per-unit-length parameters of the TL are independent of frequency. This is also an approximation that depends on the spectral content of the propagating

For very wideband signals, the attenuation and phase constants will, in general both be functions of frequency.

For most practical TLs, we find that $RC > GL$.

In order to satisfy the distortionless line requirement, series loading coils are typically placed periodically along the line to increase $L$.

# ELECTRICAL LENGTH

Electrical length is used in designs with transmission lines prior to establishing the physical length of the line.

The electrical length of a line is expressed either as a fraction of a wavelength or in degrees (or radians), where a wavelength corresponds to $360^{\circ}$ (or $2\pi$ radians).

So, if $\beta$ is the phase constant of a signal on the line and $l_{e} \stackrel{i}{\rightarrow}$ its physical length, the electrical length of the line in radians is $\beta l$.

# Example : Physical and Electrical Length

A transmission line is 10 cm long and at the operating frequency the phase constant $\beta$ is $30\, rad/m$. What is the electrical length of the line?

# Solution

The physical length of the line is $l=10\,cm=0.1\,m$. Then the electrical length of the line is $l_e=\beta l=\left(30\frac{rad}{m}\right)\times0.1\,m=3\,\mathrm{radians}$. The electrical length can also be expressed in terms of wavelength noting that $360^\circ$ corresponds to $2\pi\,\mathrm{radians}$, which also corresponds to $\lambda$. Thus $l_e=3\,\mathrm{radians}=3\times360/(2\pi)=171.9^\circ$ or $l_e=3/(2\pi)\lambda=0.477\,\lambda$

# Voltage Reflection Coefficient

The total voltage on the line can be written as the phasor sum of incident and reflected waves

$$
\begin{array}{rl} { { \tilde { V } } ( z ) = V _ { 0 } ^{+} ( e ^{- j \beta z} + \Gamma e ^{j \beta z} ) , } & { } \\{ { \tilde { I } } ( z ) = { \frac { V _ { 0 } ^{+} } { Z _ { 0 } } } \; ( e ^{- j \beta z} - \Gamma e ^{j \beta z} ) . } & { } \end{array}
$$

The amplitude of the reflected voltage wave Normalized to the amplitude of the incident voltage wave is defined as the voltage reflection coefficient, $\Gamma$

The voltage and current on the line consist of a superposition of an incident and a reflected wave; such waves are called standing waves

Only when $\Gamma=0$, there is no reflected wave. To obtain $\Gamma=0$, the load impedance $Z_{L}$ must be equal to the characteristic impedance $Z_{0}$ of the transmission line. Such a load is said to be matched to the line since there is no

![](images/229420fa93114038657aa34c307aac1a5abb0ff6887d007f39c9c7b2593983af_41.jpg){width=41%}

$$
\begin{array}{rl} & { \Gamma = \frac { V _ { 0 } ^{-} } { V _ { 0 } ^{+} } = \frac { Z _ { L } - Z _ { 0 } } { Z _ { L } + Z _ { 0 } } } \\& {  = \frac { Z _ { L } / Z _ { 0 } - 1 } { Z _ { L } / Z _ { 0 } + 1 }  \mathrm { R e f l e c t i o n ~ c o e f f i c i e n t } } \\& {  = \frac { Z _ { L } - 1 } { Z _ { L } + 1 }  ( \mathrm { d i m e n s i o n l e s s } ) ,  ( 2 . 3 ) } \end{array}
$$

$Z_{\mathrm{\~L\~}}=\frac{Z_{\mathrm{\~L\~}}}{Z_{0}}$ Normalized load impedance

$Z_{L}= Z_{0}\rightarrow\Gamma=0$: Load is matched to the line i.e., no standing waves

# Example 2-3:

A 100 $\Omega$ TL is connected to a load consisting of a $50\Omega$ resistor in series with a $10$ pF capacitor. Find the reflection coefficient at the load for a $100MHz$ signal.

Solution: The following quantities are given $R_{\mathrm{\~L\~}}=50$, $C_{\mathrm{\~L\~}}=10$ pF = $10^{-11}$ F, $Z_{0}=$ 100, $f=$ 100 MHz = $10^{8}$ Hz.

The normalized load impedance is

$$
\begin{array}{rl} { z _ { \mathrm { L } } = \frac { Z _ { \mathrm { L } } } { Z _ { 0 } } } & { = \frac { R _ { \mathrm { L } } - j / ( \omega C _ { \mathrm { L } } ) } { Z _ { 0 } } } \\& { = \frac { 1 } { 10 0 } \left( 50 - j \frac { 1 } { 2 \pi \times 10 ^{8} \times 10 ^{- 11} } \right) } \\& { = ( 0 . 5 - j 1 . 59 ) \Omega . } \end{array}
$$

![](images/3109b158658c8db63682cf912306e3ee9987cfd466a0c3eb8c53064581bcd659_47.jpg){width=47%}

<br><span class='markdown-page-line'>---------------------------------------------<span id='page32' class='markdown-page-text'>[ 第32页 ]</span>---------------------------------------------</span><br><br>

From Eq. (2.59), the voltage reflection coefficient is

$$
\begin{array}{rl} & { \Gamma = \frac { z _ { \mathrm { L } } - 1 } { z _ { \mathrm { L } } + 1 } = \frac { 0 . 5 - j 1 . 59 - 1 } { 0 . 5 - j 1 . 59 + 1 } } \\& { = \frac { - 0 . 5 - j 1 . 59 } { 1 . 5 - j 1 . 59 } = \frac { - 1 . 67 e ^{j 72 . 6 ^ { \circ} } } { 2 . 19 e ^{- j 46 . 7 ^ { \circ} } } = - 0 . 76 e ^{j 11 9 . 3 ^ { \circ} } . } \end{array}
$$

This result may be converted into the form of Eq. (2.62) by replacing the minus sign with $e^{-j180^\circ}$. Thus,

$$
\Gamma = 0 . 76 e ^{j 11 9 . 3 ^ { \circ} } e ^{- j 18 0 ^ { \circ} } = 0 . 76 e ^{- j 60 . 7 ^ { \circ} } = 0 . 76 \angle - 60 . 7 ^{\circ} ,
$$

or

$$
| \Gamma | = 0 . 76 , \, \theta _ { \mathrm { r } } = - 60 . 7 ^{\circ}
$$

# Example 2-5

A $50\Omega$ TL is terminated in a load with $Z_{\mathrm{L}}=(100+j50)\Omega$. Find the voltage reflection coefficient and the voltage standing-wave ratio.

Solution: From Eq. (2.59), is given by

$$
\Gamma = \frac { z _ { L } - 1 } { z _ { L } + 1 } = \frac { ( 2 + j 1 ) - 1 } { ( 2 + j 1 ) + 1 } = \frac { 1 + j 1 } { 3 + j 1 } .
$$

Converting the numerator and denominator to polar form yields

$$
\Gamma = \frac { 1 . 41 4 e ^{j 45 ^ { \circ} } } { 3 . 16 2 e ^{j 18 . 4 ^ { \circ} } } = 0 . 45 e ^{j 26 . 6 ^ { \circ} } .
$$

Using the definition for $S$ given by Eq. (2.73), we have

$$
S = \frac { 1 + | \Gamma | } { 1 - | \Gamma | } = \frac { 1 + 0 . 45 } { 1 - 0 . 45 } = 2 . 6 .
$$

# Standing Waves

When the load is mismatched, however, the presence of a reflected wave leads to standing waves, and the magnitude of the voltage on the line is not constant. Thus

$$
\begin{array}{rl} & { | V ( z ) | = | V _ { o } ^{+} | | 1 + \Gamma e ^{2 j \beta z} | = | V _ { o } ^{+} | | 1 + \Gamma e ^{- 2 j \beta \ell} | } \\& { = | V _ { o } ^{+} | | 1 + | \Gamma | e ^{j ( \theta - 2 \beta \ell )} | , } \end{array}
$$

Where $l$ = -z is the positive distance measured from the load at $z=0$, and $\theta$ is the phase of the reflection coefficient ($\Gamma=|\Gamma|e^{j\theta}$). This result shows that the voltage magnitude oscillates with position $z$ along the line. The maximum value occurs when the phase term $e^{j(\theta-2\beta)}=1$ and is given by $V_{\max}=|V_{o}^{+}|(1+|\Gamma|)$.

The minimum value occurs when the phase term $e^{j(\theta-2\beta)}=-1$

$V_{\mathrm{min}}=|V_{o}^{+}|(1-\left|\Gamma\right|).$

![](images/9c19e04998a27b18cecebb0bc99c7c4ad541cfd2d532373245b7208c67e9015a_31.jpg){width=31%}

Remember: Standing wave is created due to interference between the traveling waves (incident & reflected)

As $|\Gamma|$ increases, the ratio of $V_{\mathrm{max}}$ to $V_{\mathrm{min}}$ increases, so a measure of the mismatch of a line, called the standing wave ratio (SWR), can be defined as

$$
\mathrm { S W R } = \frac { V _ { \operatorname* { m a x } } } { V _ { \operatorname* { m i n } } } = \frac { 1 + | \Gamma | } { 1 - | \Gamma | } . ~ 1 \leq \mathrm { S W R } \leq \infty ,
$$

SWR < 2 is usually considered a "good match" Some applications require SWR < 1.1 or better.

# Standing Wave Patterns

The standing wave patterns provide the maximum and minimum values of voltage at each location on the transmission line for given load and generator.

The patterns present a succession of maxima and minima which repeat in space with a period of $\lambda$T2, due to constructive or destructive interference between forward and reflected (backward) waves.

If the load is matched to the transmission line ($Z_{L} = Z_{0}$) the voltage standing wave pattern is flat, with value $|V_{0}^{\dagger}|$.

If the load is infinite (open circuit), $Z_{L}=\infty$, the voltage standing wave pattern starts with a maximum at the load.

If the load is zero (short circuit), $Z_{L} = 0$, the voltage standing wave pattern starts with a minimum at the load.

![](images/f40a9168587815b5ee67891cebd5b8bb9e385c8af00b644519f536f8ca3f7d37_28.jpg){width=28%}

\left| \widetilde { V } ( d ) \right| = \left| V _ { 0 } ^{+} \right| \left[ 1 + \left| \Gamma \right| ^{2} + 2 \left| \Gamma \right| \cos ( 2 \beta d - \theta _ { \mathrm { r } } ) \right] ^{1 /}
$$

Let $d_{max}$ and $d_{min}$ be the distances from the load at which $|V(d)|$ is a maximum and a minimum, respectively.

# Measurement Of The Voltage Standing Wave Pattern

A slotted-line probe is used to measure the unknown impedance of a load, $Z_{\mathrm{L}}$.

A coaxial slotted line contains a narrow longitudinal slit in the outer conductor.

A small probe inserted in the slit can be used to sample the magnitude of the electric field and, hence, the magnitude $|V(d)|$ of the voltage on the line .

By moving the probe along the length of the slotted line, it is possible to measure $|V|\max$ and $|V|\min$ and the distances from the load at which they occur.

Then calculate $S = |V|\max / |V|\min$

![](images/744196457b9e8fd93c60683456f879b46f157828cfb234e7e3b5f146045e2cbb_25.jpg){width=25%}

# Measurement of Unknown Impedance $Z_{L}$

A measurement of the voltage standing wave pattern provides the locations of the first voltage maximum and of the first voltage minimum with respect to the load.

The ratio of the voltage magnitude at these points gives directly the voltage standing wave ratio (VSWR).

This information is sufficient to determine the load impedance $Z_{L}$, if the characteristic impedance of the transmission line $Z_{0}$ is known.

STEP 1: The VSWR provides the magnitude of the load reflection coefficient

$$
\left| \Gamma \right| = { \frac { S - 1 } { S + 1 } }
$$

<br><span class='markdown-page-line'>---------------------------------------------<span id='page42' class='markdown-page-text'>[ 第42页 ]</span>---------------------------------------------</span><br><br>

# Measurement of Unknown Impedance $Z_{L}$

STEP 2: The distance from the load of the first maximum or minimum gives the phase of the reflection coefficient.

$$
\begin{array}{rl} { 2 \beta d _ { \mathrm { m a x } } - \theta _ { \mathrm { r } } = 2 n \pi , } & { } \\{ ( 2 \beta d _ { \mathrm { m i n } } - \theta _ { \mathrm { r } } ) = ( 2 n + 1 ) \pi } & { } \end{array}
$$

STEP 3: The load impedance is obtained by.

$$
Z _ { \mathrm { L } } = Z _ { 0 } \left[ { \frac { 1 + \Gamma } { 1 - \Gamma } } \right]
$$

<br><span class='markdown-page-line'>---------------------------------------------<span id='page43' class='markdown-page-text'>[ 第43页 ]</span>---------------------------------------------</span><br><br>

# Example 2-6: Measuring $Z_{\mathrm{\~L\~}}$ with a Slotted Line

![](images/6f49604ec215bb3078c376979ae04e49daa05e40c5e3dcc422a179e888772f13_45.jpg){width=45%}

Solution: The following quantities are given:

$$
\begin{array}{r} { Z _ { 0 } = 50 \; \Omega , } \\{ S = 3 , } \\{ d _ { \mathrm { m i n } } = 12 \; \mathrm { c m } . } \end{array}
$$

Since the distance between successive voltage minima is $\lambda/2$,

$$
\lambda = 2 \times 0 . 3 = 0 . 6 \, \mathrm { m } ,
$$

and

$$
\beta = { \frac { 2 \pi } { \lambda } } = { \frac { 2 \pi } { 0 . 6 } } = { \frac { 10 \pi } { 3 } }  ( \mathrm { r a d / m } ) .
$$

From Eq. (2.73), solving for $|\Gamma|$ in terms of $S$ gives

$$
\begin{array}{r} { | \Gamma | = \frac { S - 1 } { S + 1 } } \\{ = \frac { 3 - 1 } { 3 + 1 } } \\{ = 0 . 5 . } \end{array}
$$

Next, we use the condition given by Eq. (2.71) to find $\theta_{\mathrm{r}}$:

$2\beta d_{\mathrm{min}}-\theta_{\mathrm{r}}=\pi$, for $n=0$ (first minimum),

which gives

$$
\begin{array}{rl} & { \theta _ { \mathrm { r } } = 2 \beta d _ { \mathrm { m i n } } - \pi } \\& { = 2 \times \frac { 10 \pi } { 3 } \times 0 . 12 - \pi } \\& { = - 0 . 2 \pi ~ ( \mathrm { r a d } ) } \\& { = - 36 ^{\circ} . } \end{array}
$$

Hence,

$$
\begin{array}{rl} & { \Gamma = | \Gamma | e ^{j \theta _ { \mathrm { r} } } } \\& { = 0 . 5 e ^{- j 36 ^ { \circ} } } \\& { = 0 . 40 5 - j 0 . 29 4 . } \end{array}
$$

Solving Eq. (2.59) for $Z_{\mathrm{\~L\~}}$, we have

$$
\begin{array}{r} { Z _ { \mathrm { L } } = Z _ { 0 } \left[ \frac { 1 + \Gamma } { 1 - \Gamma } \right] } \\{ = 50 \left[ \frac { 1 + 0 . 40 5 - j 0 . 29 4 } { 1 - 0 . 40 5 + j 0 . 29 4 } \right] } \end{array}
$$

# Example

A 100-$\Omega$ transmission line is connected to a load consisting of a 50-$\Omega$ resistor in series with a 10-pF capacitor. Find the reflection coefficient at the load for a 100-MHz signal.

# Solution

f=100 MHz

$$
\begin{aligned} Z_{L}=R_{L}+\frac{1}{j \omega C_{L}} \\Z_{L}=R_{L}-\frac{J}{\omega C_{L}} \\=50-\frac{j}{(2 \pi)\left(10^{8}\right)} \left(10^{-11}\right)=50-159 j(\Omega) \end{aligned}
$$

$$
\Gamma = \frac { Z _ { L } - Z _ { 0 } } { Z _ { L } + Z _ { 0 } } = \frac { 50 - 15 9 j - 10 0 } { 50 - 15 9 j + 10 0 } = \frac { - 50 - 15 9 j } { 15 0 - 15 9 j }
$$

![](images/aa4e74ad231ac2986b9187253193cd45ac1bd5e77cb9aedb6913775f8fd8c3ee_30.jpg){width=30%}

Can rationalize the denominator and divide

$$
\Gamma = \frac { - 50 - 15 9 j } { 15 0 - 15 9 j } \Big [ \frac { 15 0 + 15 9 j } { 15 0 + 15 9 j } \Big ] = . 37 21 - . 66 55 j = 0 . 76 \angle - 60 . 8 ^{\circ}
$$

or convert to polar form, then divide

$$
\Gamma = \frac { 16 6 . 7 \angle - 10 7 . 5 ^{\circ} } { 21 8 . 6 \angle - 46 . 7 ^{\circ} } = \frac { 16 6 . 7 } { 21 8 . 6 } \angle ( - 10 7 . 5 - - 46 . 7 ) = 0 . 76 \angle - 60 . 8 ^{\circ}
$$

# What does this mean?

76% of the wave is reflected at the load and is phase shifted by $-60.8^{\circ}$.

# Wave Impedance

At a distance $d$ from the load: the input impedance (Wave Impedance)

$$
\begin{array}{rl} & { Z ( d ) \; = \; \frac { \tilde { V } ( d ) } { \tilde { I } ( d ) } } \\& {  = \; \frac { V _ { 0 } ^{+} [ e ^{j \beta d} + \Gamma e ^{- j \beta d} ] } { V _ { 0 } ^{+} [ e ^{j \beta d} - \Gamma e ^{- j \beta d} ] } \; Z _ { 0 } } \\& {  = \; Z _ { 0 } \left[ \frac { 1 + \Gamma e ^{- j 2 \beta d} } { 1 - \Gamma e ^{- j 2 \beta d} } \right] } \\& {  = \; Z _ { 0 } \left[ \frac { 1 + \Gamma _ { d } } { 1 - \Gamma _ { d } } \right]  ( \Omega ) , } \end{array}
$$

where we define

$$
\Gamma _ { d } = \Gamma e ^{- j 2 \beta d} = | \Gamma | e ^{j \theta _ { \mathrm { r} } } e ^{- j 2 \beta d} = | \Gamma | e ^{j ( \theta _ { \mathrm { r} } - 2 \beta d ) }
$$

as the phase-shifted voltage reflection coefficient,

![](images/a8745d43cb0c990123f109f7f06d55de1baafa555090982eecbee689d774d04f_45.jpg){width=45%} (b) Equivalent circuit

Z(d) is the ratio of the total voltage (incident and reflected-wave voltages) to the total current at any point d on the line, in contrast with the characteristic impedance of the line Z₀, which relates the voltage and current of each of the two waves individually (Z₀=V⁺₀/I⁺₀=-V⁻₀/I⁻₀).

<br><span class='markdown-page-line'>---------------------------------------------<span id='page46' class='markdown-page-text'>[ 第46页 ]</span>---------------------------------------------</span><br><br>

# Input Impedance

![](images/80eb58c94e9356d97e326555d8ca66439c7183b56698870a398ed395445ba582_42.jpg){width=42%}

$$
Z _ { \mathrm { i n } } = Z ( l ) = Z _ { 0 } \left[ \frac { 1 + \Gamma _ { l } } { 1 - \Gamma _ { l } } \right] .
$$

$$
\Gamma _ { l } = \Gamma e ^{- j 2 \beta l} = | \Gamma | e ^{j ( \theta _ { \mathrm { r} } - 2 \beta l ) } .
$$

$$
\begin{array}{rl} & { Z _ { \mathrm { i n } } = Z _ { 0 } \left( \frac { z _ { \mathrm { L } } \cos \beta l + j \sin \beta l } { \cos \beta l + j z _ { \mathrm { L } } \sin \beta l } \right) } \\& { = Z _ { 0 } \left( \frac { z _ { \mathrm { L } } + j \tan \beta l } { 1 + j z _ { \mathrm { L } } \tan \beta l } \right) . } \end{array}
$$

At input, $d = \lceil$:

Fig. 2-18. The phasor voltage across $Z_{\mathrm{in}}$ is given by

$$
\widetilde { V } _ { \mathrm { i } } = \tilde { I } _ { \mathrm { i } } Z _ { \mathrm { i n } } = \frac { \tilde { V } _ { \mathrm { g } } Z _ { \mathrm { i n } } } { Z _ { \mathrm { g } } + Z _ { \mathrm { i n } } } ~ ,
$$

Simultaneously, from the standpoint of the transmission line, the voltage across it at the input of the line is given by Eq.(2.63a) with $z = -l$:

$$
\tilde { V } _ { i } = \tilde { V } ( - l ) = V _ { 0 } ^{+} [ e ^{j \beta l} + \Gamma e ^{- j \beta l} ] .
$$

Equating Eq. (2.80) to Eq. (2.81) and then solving for $V_{0}^{+}$ leads to

$$
V _ { 0 } ^{+} = \left( \frac { \widetilde { V _ { g } } Z _ { \mathrm { i n } } } { Z _ { \mathrm { g } } + Z _ { \mathrm { i n } } } \right) \left( \frac { 1 } { e j \beta l } + \Gamma e ^{- j \beta l} \right) .
$$

A 1.05 GHz generator circuit with series impedance $Z_{\mathrm{g}}=10 \Omega$ and voltage source given by $\nu_{\mathrm{g}}(t)=10 \sin(\omega t+30^{\circ})$ (V) is connected to a load $Z_{\mathrm{L}}=(100+j50) \Omega$ through a $50 \Omega$, $67 \mathrm{\~cm}$ long lossless TL. From the relationship $u_{\mathrm{p}}=\lambda f$, we find the wavelength

$$
\begin{array}{rl} { \lambda = \frac { u _ { \mathrm { p } } } { f } } & { { } = \frac { 0 . 7 \times 3 \times 10 ^{8} } { 1 . 05 \times 10 ^{9} } = 0 . 2 \, \mathrm { m } , } \end{array}
$$

and

$$
\beta l = \frac { 2 \pi } { \lambda } ~ l ~ ~ ~ = \frac { 2 \pi } { 0 . 2 } \times 0 . 67 ~ ~ ~ = 6 . 7 \pi = 0 . 7 \pi = 12 6 ^{\circ} ,
$$

where we have subtracted multiples of $2\pi$.

The voltage reflection coefficient at the load is

$$
\Gamma = \frac { Z _ { \mathrm { L } } - Z _ { 0 } } { Z _ { \mathrm { L } } + Z _ { 0 } } = \frac { ( 10 0 + j 50 ) - 50 } { ( 10 0 + j 50 ) + 50 } = 0 . 45 e ^{j 26 . 6 ^ { \circ} } .
$$

$$
\begin{array}{rl} & { Z _ { \mathrm { i n } } = Z _ { 0 } \left( \frac { 1 + \Gamma _ { l } } { 1 - \Gamma _ { l } } \right) = Z _ { 0 } \left( \frac { 1 + \Gamma e ^{- j 2 \beta l} } { 1 - \Gamma e ^{- j 2 \beta l} } \right) } \\& { = 50 \left( \frac { 1 + 0 . 45 e ^{j 26 . 6 ^ { \circ} } e ^{- j 25 2 ^ { \circ} } } { 1 - 0 . 45 e ^{j 26 . 6 ^ { \circ} } e ^{- j 25 2 ^ { \circ} } } \right) = ( 21 . 9 + j 17 . 4 ) ~ \Omega . } \end{array}
$$

# The Time-average Power

A transmission line is used to transfer power from the source to the load. The time-average power flow along the line at point z is given by

![](images/a6558456aff500331e778ee4751811f33bfc4d29902419800975eb8f4deaab93_63.jpg){width=63%}

The first term is the incident power $P_{a}^{i}$, while the second term is the reflected power $P^{r}$

$$
P _ { \mathrm { a v } } ^{\mathrm { i} } = \frac { | V _ { 0 } ^{+} | ^{2} } { 2 Z _ { 0 } }  ( W ) ,
$$

![](images/1fe42cdd78bda0b38460bfb54a7de59e2316473743c93d3f759412d655c31d9d_47.jpg){width=47%}

$$
P _ { \mathrm { a v } } ^{\mathrm { r} } = - | \Gamma | ^{2} \frac { | V _ { 0 } ^{+} | ^{2} } { 2 Z _ { 0 } } = - | \Gamma | ^{2} P _ { \mathrm { a v } } ^{\mathrm { i} } .
$$

The average reflected power is equal to the average incident power, diminished by a multiplicative factor of $|\Gamma|^2$.

# The Time-average Power

$\Gamma=0$ $\rightarrow$ Maximum power is delivered to the load

$|\Gamma|=1$ $\rightarrow$ No power is delivered to the load

When the load is mismatched, not all of the available power from the generator is delivered to the load. This "loss" is called return loss (RL), and is defined (in dB) as

$$
\begin{array}{r} { \boxed { \mathrm { R L } = - 20 \log | \Gamma | ~ \mathrm { d B } } \\{ \boxed { \mathrm { o r ~ } R L ~ = ~ - 10 l o g \frac { P _ { i } } { P _ { r } } ~ ~ ~ \mathrm { d B } } \end{array}
$$

Matched load ($\Gamma=0$)→ $RL=\infty dB$ (no reflected power)

Total Reflection ($|\Gamma|=1$)→ $RL=\infty dB$ (all incident power is reflected)

Return loss is a nonnegative number for reflection from a passive network.

Example 2-8: Equivalent Reactive Elements

Choose the length of a shorted 50-$\Omega$ lossless transmission line (Fig. 2-20) such that its input impedance at 2.25 GHz is identical to that of a capacitor with capacitance $C_{\mathrm{eq}}=4$ pF. The wave velocity on the line is 0.75c.

![](images/2aebec3eb2c222bb26cce14ebda36619f30f4cf9843c64e8f63fa76c2650f933_45.jpg){width=45%}

Solution: We are given

$$
\begin{array}{rl} & { u _ { \mathrm { p } } = 0 . 75 c = 0 . 75 \times 3 \times 10 ^{8} = 2 . 25 \times 10 ^{8} ~ \mathrm { m / s } , } \\& { Z _ { 0 } = 50 ~ \Omega , } \\& { f = 2 . 25 ~ \mathrm { G H z } = 2 . 25 \times 10 ^{9} ~ \mathrm { H z } , } \\& { C _ { \mathrm { e q } } = 4 ~ \mathrm { p F } = 4 \times 10 ^{- 12} ~ \mathrm { F } . } \end{array}
$$

The phase constant is

$$
\beta = \frac { 2 \pi } { \lambda } = \frac { 2 \pi f } { u _ { \mathrm { p } } } = \frac { 2 \pi \times 2 . 25 \times 10 ^{9} } { 2 . 25 \times 10 ^{8} } = 62 . 8 ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ( \mathrm { r a d / m } ) .
$$

From Eq. (2.89), it follows that

$$
\begin{array}{rl} & { \tan \beta l = - \frac { 1 } { Z _ { 0 } \omega C _ { \mathrm { e q } } } } \\& { = - \frac { 1 } { 50 \times 2 \pi \times 2 . 25 \times 10 ^{9} \times 4 \times 10 ^{- 12} } } \\& { = - 0 . 35 4 . } \end{array}
$$

The tangent function is negative when its argument is in the second or fourth quadrants. The solution for the second quadrant is

$$
\beta l _ { 1 } = 2 . 8 \, \mathrm { r a d }  \mathrm { o r }  l _ { 1 } = \frac { 2 . 8 } { \beta } = \frac { 2 . 8 } { 62 . 8 } = 4 . 46 \, \mathrm { c m } ,
$$

and the solution for the fourth quadrant is

$$
\beta l _ { 2 } = 5 . 94 \, \mathrm { r a d }  \mathrm { o r }  l _ { 2 } = { \frac { 5 . 94 } { 62 . 8 } } = 9 . 46 \, \mathrm { c m } .
$$

# Example 2-9:

Find $Z_{0}$ and $\beta$ of a 57 cm long lossless TL whose input impedance was measured as $Z_{\mathrm{in}}^{\mathrm{sc}}=j40.42\Omega$ when terminated in a short circuit and as $Z_{\mathrm{in}}^{o c}=-j121.24\Omega$ when terminated in an open circuit. From other measurements, we know that the line is between 3 and 3.25 wavelengths long.

# Solution:

$$
\begin{array}{rl} & { \mathrm { ~ c ~ o ~ m ~ E q s . ~ ( 2 . 94 ) ~ a n d ~ ( 2 . 95 ) , }  Z _ { 0 } = \sqrt [ + ] { Z _ { \mathrm { i n } } ^{\mathrm { s c} } \, Z _ { \mathrm { i n } } ^{\mathrm { o c} } } = \sqrt { ( j 40 . 42 ) ( - j 12 1 . 24 ) } = 70 \; \Omega , } \\& { \tan \beta l = \sqrt { \frac { - Z _ { \mathrm { i n } } ^{\mathrm { s c} } } { Z _ { \mathrm { i n } } ^{\mathrm { o c} } } } = \sqrt { \frac { 1 } { 3 } } . } \end{array}
$$

Since $l$ is between $3\lambda$ and $3.25\lambda$, $\theta l = (2\pi l/\lambda)$ is between $6\pi$ radians and $(13\pi/2)$ radians. This places $\theta l$ in the first quadrant ($0$ to $\pi/2$) radians. Hence, the only acceptable solution for $\tan \theta = \sqrt{1/3}$ is $\theta l = \pi/6$ radians. This value, however, does not include the $2\pi$ multiples associated with the integer $\lambda$ multiples of $l$. Hence, the true value of $\theta l$ is

$$
\beta l = 6 \pi + { \frac { \pi } { 6 } } = 19 . 4  ( \mathrm { r a d } ) ,
$$

in which case

$$
\beta = \frac { 19 . 4 } { 0 . 57 } = 34 ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ( \mathrm { r a d / m } ) .
$$

2-8.4 Lines of Length $l = n\lambda/2$

If $l = n\lambda/2$, where $n$ is an integer,

$$
\tan \beta l \, = \tan { [ ( 2 \pi / \lambda ) \, ( n \lambda / 2 ) ] } = \tan n \pi \, = 0 .
$$

Consequently, Eq. (2.79) reduces to

$$
Z _ { \mathrm { i n } } = Z _ { \mathrm { L } } , ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ \mathrm { f o r } ~ l = n \lambda / 2 , ~ ~ ~ ~ ( 2 . 96 )
$$

which means that a half-wavelength line (or any integer multiple of $\lambda/2$) does not modify the load impedance.

# Input Impedance of Special Cases

Consider a transmission line of characteristic impedance $Z_0$ feeding a line of different characteristic impedance, $Z_l$.

![](images/3024e9a08f7d4b7540026a7eec09e147f4054b6f30ceab230e6b1b748836f2b6_33.jpg){width=33%}

If the load line is infinitely long, or if it is terminated in its own characteristic impedance, so that there are no reflections from its far end, then the input impedance seen by the feed line is $Z_{l}$, so that the reflection coefficient is

$$
\Gamma = \frac { Z _ { 1 } - Z _ { 0 } } { Z _ { 1 } + Z _ { 0 } } .
$$

Not all of the incident wave is reflected; some is transmitted onto the second line. The transmission coefficient, $T$, is expressed as

$$
\boxed { T = 1 + \Gamma = 1 + \frac { Z _ { 1 } - Z _ { 0 } } { Z _ { 1 } + Z _ { 0 } } = \frac { 2 Z _ { 1 } } { Z _ { 1 } + Z _ { 0 } } . }
$$

dB as the insertion loss, IL The transmission coefficient between two points in a circuit is often expressed in 1B as the insertion loss TI

$$
\mathrm { I L } = - 20 \log | T | \, \mathrm { d B } .
$$

# Lossy Transmission Lines

For a lossy line, $Z_{in}$ can be expressed as

$$
Z _ { \mathrm { i n } } = Z _ { 0 } \left[ \frac { Z _ { L } + Z _ { 0 } \operatorname { t a n h } \gamma \ell } { Z _ { 0 } + Z _ { L } \operatorname { t a n h } \gamma \ell } \right] ~ ~ ~ ( \mathrm { l o s s y } )
$$

The power delivered to the input of the terminated line at $\overline{z}=-l$ is

$$
P _ { \mathrm { i n } } = \frac { | V _ { o } ^{+} | ^{2} } { 2 Z _ { 0 } } ( 1 - | \Gamma ( \ell ) | ^{2} ) e ^{2 \alpha \ell} \, ,
$$

$$
\begin{array}{r} { V ( z ) , I ( z ) } \\{ Z _ { \mathrm { i n } } \Longrightarrow   Z _ { 0 } , \alpha , \beta } \\{ - l } \end{array} \Longrightarrow \begin{array}{rl} { Z _ { L } } & { { } } \\{ 0 } & { { } } \end{array} \Rightarrow
$$

where $\Gamma(l)$ is the the reflection coefficient at a distance $l$ from the load is

$$
\Gamma ( \ell ) = \Gamma e ^{- 2 j \beta \ell} e ^{- 2 \alpha \ell} = \Gamma e ^{- 2 \gamma \ell} .
$$

The power delivered to the load is

$$
P _ { L } = \frac { | V _ { o } ^{+} | ^{2} } { 2 Z _ { 0 } } ( 1 - | \Gamma | ^{2} ) .
$$

The difference in these powers corresponds to the power lost in the line:

$$
P _ { \mathrm { l o s s } } = P _ { \mathrm { i n } } - P _ { L } = \frac { | V _ { o } ^{+} | ^{2} } { 2 Z _ { 0 } } [ ( e ^{2 \alpha \ell} - 1 ) + | \Gamma | ^{2} ( 1 - e ^{- 2 \alpha \ell} ) ] .
$$

The first term accounts for the power loss of the incident wave, while the second term accounts for the power loss of the reflected wave; note that both terms increase as $\alpha$ increases.

A complex number may be represented as

$$
\begin{array}{rl} & { z = x + j y = r \sqrt { \theta } = r e ^{j \theta} = r \left( \cos \theta + j \sin \theta \right) } \\& { { \mathrm { w h e r e ~ } } x = { \mathrm { R e } } \, z = r \cos \theta ,  y = { \mathrm { I m } } \, z = r \sin \theta } \\& { r = | z | = { \sqrt { x ^{2} + y ^{2} } } ,  \theta = \tan ^{- 1} { \frac { y } { x } } } \\& { j = { \sqrt { - 1 } } ,  { \frac { 1 } { j } } = - j ,  j ^{2} = - 1 } \end{array}
$$

The complex conjugate of $z = z^* = x - jy = r\angle -\theta = re^{-j\theta}$

$$
\begin{array}{rl} & { : = z ^{\star} = x - j y = r \angle - \theta = r e ^{- j \theta} } \\& { = r \left( \cos \theta - j \sin \theta \right) } \\& { ( e ^{j \theta} ) ^{n} = e ^{j n \theta} = \cos n \theta + j \sin n \theta  \mathrm { ~ ( d e ~ M o i v r e ' s ~ t h e o r e m ) } } \end{array}
$$

If $z_{1} = x_{1} + jy_{1}$ and $z_{2} = x_{2} + jy_{2}$, then $z_{1} = z_{2}$ only if $x_{1} = x_{2}$ and $y_{1} = y_{2}$.

$$
\begin{array}{rl} & { z _ { 1 } \pm z _ { 2 } = ( x _ { 1 } + x _ { 2 } ) \pm j ( y _ { 1 } + y _ { 2 } ) } \\& { z _ { 1 } z _ { 2 } = ( x _ { 1 } x _ { 2 } - y _ { 1 } y _ { 2 } ) + j ( x _ { 1 } y _ { 2 } + x _ { 2 } y _ { 1 } ) } \end{array}
$$

$$
z _ { 1 } z _ { 2 } = r _ { 1 } r _ { 2 } \, e ^{j ( \theta _ { 1} + \theta _ { 2 } ) } = r _ { 1 } r _ { 2 } / \theta _ { 1 } + \theta _ { 2 }
$$
